c74object.name: bach.lookup
c74object.digest: Return specific elements of an llll (inlets reversed)
c74object.description: Returns one or more specific elements of an llll, based on their addresses. It works exactly like bach.nth, but with reversed inlets.

objarg.name: original
objarg.description: A default llll to retrieve elements from can be set as bach.lookup's argument.

method.name: bang
method.description: Returns the requested elements according to the most recently received lllls.

method.name: llll
method.description:
An llll in first inlet sets the address of the elements to extract, extract such elements and outputs them. An llll in second inlet sets the llll from which elements should be extracted. An address is an llll providing a unique representation of the position of an element in another llll. It is a concept shared by many bach object. The address of each element of an llll's root level is simply its position counting from 1. The address of an element in a sublist is a list composed by the position of the element in the sublist, preceded by the position of the sublist in the parent llll, and so on up to the root level, as a sort of "path" to the element.
For instance, given the llll a b c (d e (f g) h i) j k the position of c is 3; the position of (d e (f g) h i) is 4; the position if e is 4 2 since to reach it it takes to go to the 4th element of the root level, which is a sublist, and to the 2nd element of that sublist. By reading the address from right to left, it can be seen that this is equivalent to saying that the pointed element is the 2nd of the 4th. Likewise, in the above llll f has the address 4 3 1 since it is the 1st of the 3rd of the 4th.
In addition, addresses sent to bach objects can contain negative positions, that is positions counted from the end of the llll instead than the right. Negative and positive positions can be safely mixed within a single address. Thus, the address of the element g can be expressed as 4 3 2 as well as 4 3 -1 or -3 -3 -1.
bach.lookup also accepts a special syntax to indicate multiple elements of one level of the llll: a sublist in the address will be interpreted as a sequence of elements in the corresponding level. In this way, the address 4 (2 4 5) means "the 2nd, 4th and 5th of the 4th", that is e h i. Negative positions are accepted here as well. Any number after the multiple-element sublist in the address llll is ignored.
The multiple-element sublist can contain sublists in its turn. These are called "range sublists". A range sublist is composed by two positions, and indicates all the elements comprised between these two positions. Either or both positions of a range sublist can be negative. So, the address 4 ((2 -1) 1) means "From the 2nd to the last (i.e. the 1st from the right) and the 1st of the 4th", that is e (f g) h i d. As a tip, notice that to retrieve all the contents of a sublist (as opposed to the sublist itself) the range (1 -1) can be specified.

attribute.name: nils
attribute.description: When set to 1, if no element was present at the requested address () is output. When set to 0 (default), null is output.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, e

attribute.name: unwrap
attribute.description: When set to 1, the outermost couple of parentheses of any sublist to be output is removed. For instance, if the llll a b (c d e) is input and its third element is requested, c d e will be output instead of (c d e). Defaults to 0.

c74object.discussion: The abstraction is a small abstraction of bach.nth.

entry.name: More details
entry.description: The abstraction is a small abstraction of bach.nth.
